greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Baum-Sweet cubic sequence.
comment: Memo: more sequences like this should be added to the database.
link: J.-P. Allouche, Finite automata and arithmetic Seminaire Lotharingien de Combinatoire, B30c (1993), 23 pp. [Formerly: Publ. I.R.M.A. Strasbourg, 1993, 1993/034, p. 1-18.]
Michael Gilleland, Some Self-Similar Integer Sequences
H. Niederreiter and M. Vielhaber, Tree complexity and a doubly exponential gap between structured and random sequences, J. Complexity, 12 (1996), 187-198.
D. P. Robbins, Cubic Laurent series in characteristic 2 with bounded partial quotients, arXiv:math/9903092 [math.NT], 1999.
formula: It appears that a(n)=sum(k=0, n-1, C(n-1+k, n-1-k)*C(n-1, k)) modulo 2 = A082759(n-1) (mod 2). It appears also that a(k)=1 iff k/3 is in A003714. - _Benoit Cloitre_, Jun 20 2003
If Cloitre's above observation holds, then we also have (assuming starting offset 0, with a(0) = 1):
maple: A := x; for n from 1 to 100 do series(x+x*A^3+O(x^(n+2)),x,n+2); A := series(% mod 2,x,n+2); od: A;
mathematica: Do[A[x_] = x + x A[x]^3 + O[x]^m // Normal // PolynomialMod[#, 2]&, {m}];
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_.
